@nothappening She said that she never had any romantic feelings for him. That right there says "You don't have a chance." What everyone else at school thinks is irrelevant. Pages 2 and 3 don't really suggest that she's trying to not to hurt or ruin the relationship, just that she was thinking of the best way to explain how their relationship actually is/was. Iori was very upfront about them just being best friends, Yuuto just couldn't accept that fact.

@steelers036 She did not forgive Yuuto, she said that she'd never forget what he did to her. She wants to stay friends with him because of the promise they made when they were kids, which is the entire reason why we're shown it in a flashback at the end after Yuuto walks away. It symbolizes him realizing that *he* was the one that broke the promise and their friendship. Don't know where y'all are getting these wildly different interpretations from when everything is literally laid out and easy to follow.
@nothappening Iori didn't use Yuuto, lmao. Did you even read the damn story?

They both had to grow up. He had to let go of his dream and she had to let go of her friend. You feel bad for Iori because she make decisions without any real thought. Yet she is very kind and never really means to hurt anybody. As for Yuuto he does not want to rock the boat and waits for an opportunity to confess that never comes.  He thinks he can fix it with saying I Love you or that it will all blow over and things will go back to normal but that time never comes. Then he does something horrible and is racked with guilt. Yet Iori forgives him and feels that being kind to Yuuto everything can go back to normal. Thats when Yuuto remembers how they met and recalls an old lesson. Things don't always work out and theres no going back.  Its a lesson that Yuuto teaches Iori. She finally realizes she cant fix this at the end and lets him go. Like I said before this manga was written to deliver pain and likes to bring up the pains of growing up.

I don’t think the story is necessarily “bad” just because it makes you sympathize for the rapist. Yes, the action he did was unforgivable, but I don’t think the story is trying to claim otherwise. The reason why he’s suffering so much in the end was because he regrets what he did, which is plainly saying that his act of rape is something to be ashamed of. Even when he’s given a chance at returning to normalcy, the story doesn’t allow him to do so, and instead acknowledges that what he did is literally irredeemable. Sympathizing with a criminal’s motives doesn’t mean at all that their actions aren’t subject to consequence. It’s okay, and possibly even good, to acknowledge that we are all capable of committing atrocities, but even if that’s a choice, that doesn’t make it the “right” one. IMO, even if I feel shitty after reading this, the story is 10/10, not shitty at all.

Some here want this to have a second part with a happy ending, while a lot think otherwise. I very much agree with the latter, this manga meant to tell a message and making a second part to satisfy a happy ending fantasy would only invalidate it. To me, the manga here depicts the growth of the mc from a boy to a man. His illusions of intimacy is shattered, he deals with emotional stress by lashing out and does smth he regrets, he runs away in distress and shame, but in the end he decides to cut ties and move on even if hes torn inside. Meanwhile i have no strong feeling towards the girl. She doesnt seem constructed like the mc is, and only serves as a device to push foward the plot for the sake of his mental development (his first love, expressing unconditional kindness, confronting him). The artist draws yaoi and the art seems quite female, so im very impressed that a woman wrote such a convincing depiction of a male character. 10/10
